docs.title: Welcome to NUTLAB
docs.text: Nutlab is the official Nutlab site for all opensource projects and playable servers in the Nutlab community. To get started, follow the latest Nutlab project below, or click the headers above to jump to another page.

docs.title: Nutlab presents its first project with openchrono2
docs.text:
openchrono2 is a new open source airsoft chronometer. To measure the speed of airsoft bb's, two light gates are spaced a set distance away from eachother. A microcontroller is used to calculate the time it takes for a bb to pass each point and calculates the speed in m/s or fps.

For more information, click here!

docs.title: Nutlab projects
docs.text: In Nutlabs we like to create software and hardware to solve everyday problems and challenge our brains. To the left is a list of projects, both open source and not avaliable to browse.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: openchrono2 is the second open source airsoft chronograph. Inspired by xythobuz this project is a full PCB and software assembly to create a budget, open source chronograph for people to make, upgrade and use.

docs.title: Xythobuz's origionnal OpenChrono project
docs.text:
Xythobuz's OpenChrono project was the inspiration for this piece, many of the components are the same, but openchrono2 features a full PCB design and some new code to accompany some of the PCB additions and changes.

The origional OpenChrono is designed as an attachable suppressor onto a airsoft replica with a 3D printed shell, whereas openchrono2 will be utilising a larger shell around a single PCB, ideal for budget and quick construction.

For the full write-up on their website click here: https://www.xythobuz.de/openchrono.html

docs.title: Single PCB
docs.text: To expand on Xythobuz's idea, openchrono2's initial production prototype will be a PCB with the chronograph section on one side and the microcontroller and display on the other section.
